author: Vitória Silva
title: Consumo de bebidas alcoólicas em Campinas cresce acima da média da região em 2024
text:
Moradores de Campinas estão consumindo mais bebidas alcoólicas, revelam os dados do IPC Maps, estudo especializado em potencial de consumo brasileiro. O consumo de álcool na cidade subiu de R$ 272,7 milhões para R$ 310,4 milhões entre 2023 e 2024, o que representa uma alta de 13,8%.
Esse aumento no percentual da metrópole é maior do que o registrado na soma das 20 cidades da RMC (Região Metropolitana de Campinas). A região teve uma alta de 10,2% entre 2023 e 2024, com o consumo passando de R$ 710 milhões para R$ 782 milhões, ainda conforme o IPC Maps. No estado de São Paulo inteiro, as despesas com bebidas alcoólicas somaram R$ 9,5 bilhões.
Hoje, dia 20 de fevereiro, marca o Dia Nacional de Combate às Drogas e ao Alcoolismo, data que busca conscientizar a população sobre os danos causados por essas substâncias.
Consumo abusivo de bebidas alcoólicas
A alta no consumo em Campinas e região acende o alerta para a ingestão abusiva de álcool. Uma pesquisa aponta que 75% dos consumidores abusivos desse tipo de bebida no Brasil acreditam que bebem de forma moderada.
O levantamento, encomendado pelo Centro de Informações sobre Saúde e Álcool, ONG que produz informações científicas para reduzir o uso nocivo de bebidas, ainda apontou que, dos consumidores abusivos, só 13% reconhecem a necessidade de mudar seus hábitos, enquanto 11% admitem que bebem muito, mas não veem isso como um problema.
Além disso, cerca de 57% dos brasileiros desconhecem ou têm uma percepção equivocada sobre o que significa beber com moderação.
Vidas em reconstrução
A equipe da EPTV conversou com pessoas que lutam contra o alcoolismo. Elas se recuperam em uma instituição de acolhimento e pediram para manter as identidades preservadas.
Para um dos entrevistados, o álcool é a droga mais perigosa que existe. Ele tem 59 anos e avisa que a história de “tomar só uma dose” é só o começo.
Os erros cometidos sob o efeito do álcool ainda o assombram. Uma vez, ele chegou a arrancar a lateral inteira do carro de uma pessoa após consumir bebidas alcoólicas e dirigir.
“Fiz tratamento, fiquei sem beber, mas um dia tomei ‘só uma dose’. Aquilo foi suficiente para perder o controle de novo. Só parei quando precisei me internar”, disse.
Outra pessoa que está em tratamento conta que, no auge da dependência, evitava sair para comprar álcool por vergonha e chegou a pagar outras pessoas para buscar a bebida por ela. O impacto emocional e físico do consumo excessivo ficou evidente quando o homem passou a se olhar no espelho e não se reconhecer mais, percebendo que precisava de ajuda.
Como buscar ajuda
Em Campinas, o Caps (Centro de Atenção Psicossocial) atende pacientes que querem deixar o álcool e as drogas. O programa chamado “Recomeço” conta com reuniões de grupos terapêuticos, em que pacientes compartilham experiências e também podem viver em alojamentos.
O tempo de permanência varia conforme cada caso. No mês passado, eram quase dois mil usuários ativos frequentando o programa de recuperação.
A unidade do Caps que conta com essa iniciativa fica na Avenida Pefeito Faria Lima, número 560, no Parque Itália.
“Seja sábio. Aprenda com os erros dos outros. Não espere chegar ao fundo do poço para buscar ajuda. Não vale a pena”, finaliza um dos entrevistados.
*Com informações de Jorge Talmon/EPTV Campinas

author: MaryLou Driedger
title: COLUMN: Viewpoint – Imagine peace – The Carillon
text: COLUMN: Viewpoint – Imagine peace Advertisement “The wolf will live with the lamb, the leopard will lie down with the goat, the calf and the lion and the yearling together; and a little child will lead them.” Isaiah 11:6 That’s one Scripture passage I’ll read on Christmas Eve when I narrate the service at my church which will lead people through the story of the birth of Christ with words and music. Jesus was called the Prince of Peace and the Isaiah passage describes a time when all of the earth will be at peace. Harm and destruction will end. Those traditionally thought of as enemies will live in harmony. Children will take the lead. The vision in Isaiah 11 seems impossible. Our world could never be like that. But this holiday season I invite you to use your imagination and start thinking about the earthly home we share with all of humanity as just such a place of peace. Several years ago, I visited a Vancouver Art Gallery exhibit with works by Yoko Ono, a well-known peace activist and wife of Beatles musician John Lennon who was shot and killed just before Christmas in 1980. One installation in the Yoko Ono exhibit was called Imagine and paid tribute to the John Lennon song Imagine whose lyrics read “Imagine all the people Living life in peace You may say I’m a dreamer But I’m not the only one I hope someday you’ll join us And the world will be as one.” The Yoko Ono art piece Imagine consisted of a gigantic world map. Stamps were available with the words ‘Imagine Peace’ on them and art gallery visitors were to ink a stamp and press it down on the map near their home. I put my stamp on Manitoba. The map had these stamped ‘Imagine Peace’ messages in hundreds of locations helping us imagine what peace across the planet might look like. On the second Sunday of advent a child from my church shared through artwork and writing what peace meant to him using his five senses. Congregation members were invited to imagine peace in a similar way. I thought about how peace is like the smell of roses- my mother-in-law’s favourite flower, the taste of the bread pudding my husband always makes for our Christmas dinner, the sound of the songs on the Christmas playlist I’ve made featuring Canadian artists, the calm of the lake at sunrise at our family cottage and the feeling I get holding my sleeping baby granddaughter in my arms. This Christmas I want to suggest that if we imagine peace, imagine a future for humanity that is peaceful and good that we may be inclined to act in ways that will help to make that peaceful, happy future a reality. This is not just some feel good idea. Scientific research tells us our brains often have a difficult time differentiating between things we see happen in our imagination and things that happen in real life. When we imagine things our brains attempt to simulate the responses that would occur if those situations had really happened. So, imagining peace can actually spur us to take actions that might just help peace become a reality within ourselves, our families, communities, and the world. We sometimes think our lives and our world are falling apart. Many people give up and believe there is nothing they can do. But is it possible that if we keep imagining peace and a peaceful future we will start living as if we believe it will happen? This Christmas season I invite you to do exactly that.

author: Ryan Dickstein
title: Homeless man left in coma after beating outside Checkers restaurant
text:
BALTIMORE — A homeless man was left in a coma after being brutally beaten while eating outside a Northeast Baltimore fast food restaurant.
Now the alleged perpetrator faces attempted murder charges, because the whole thing was caught on video.
It happened after midnight on April 17.
Charging documents say the 40-year-old victim had just ordered food from the pickup window of Checkers on Moravia Road.
After sitting down to eat, charging documents say the victim was approached by 34-year-old Deluntae Boyd.
Surveillance shows Boyd looking through the victim's food bag, snatching it, and then walking away.
The victim reportedly yells something at Boyd, prompting him to turn back around.
This is when detectives say Boyd pushed the victim down, causing his head to hit the table.
According to charging documents, Boyd then beat the victim into unconsciousness, punching him 10 times while stomping his head eight times.
By the time police arrived on scene, Boyd had fled. The victim was already taken to a hospital, and was unresponsive with a brain bleed.
Detectives identified Boyd by his outfit the night of the attack.
An officer spotted him walking around the next day wearing the same exact clothing.
When brought in for questioning, detectives showed Boyd surveillance photos of the wanted suspect, at which time he reportedly replied "that looks like me, y'all must have a clone of me or something."
Online court records show Boyd with a criminal record including past convictions of assault (2014) and unauthorized use (2017). In both cases Boyd was given an 18 month suspended jail sentence. He was also convicted in Harford County in 2021 for telephone misuse, in which he was given one year of probation.
Boyd is now being held without bail, and is next due in court on May 14.

author: ansa.it
title: Tributaristi, 'tutele per malattia non solo a iscritti a Ordini' - Fisco e Lavoro - Ansa.it
text: "Nonostante le sue giuste finalità, la norma sulla tutela dei professionisti in malattia, o infortunio" del 2021 "continua a perpetrare discriminazioni tra professionisti ordinistici e professionisti associativi", visto che "lo scorso 11 settembre con un emendamento approvato alla Camera, presentato dal deputato Andrea de Bertoldi (primo firmatario anche della disciplina originaria, varata nella scorsa Legislatura, ndr), la tutela, che prevede la sospensione degli adempimenti fiscali in caso di malattia o infortunio, viene giustamente estesa allo stato di maternità a rischio e alla malattia dei figli minori, sempre, però, riservando la tutela ai professionisti ordinistici, ignorando gli oltre 480.000 fra professioniste e professionisti iscritti alla gestione separata dell'Inps". Lo afferma il presidente dell'Istituto nazionale tributaristi (Int) Riccardo Alemanno, che nei giorni scorsi aveva rinnovato al ministro delle Imprese e del made in Italy Adolfo Urso la richiesta di modifica della legge, estendendola alle professioniste e ai professionisti associativi, e ha inviato, congiuntamente alla consigliera nazionale con delega alle Pari opportunità Monica Cerva, una nota alla ministra della Famiglia Eugenia Maria Roccella, evidenziando come una giusta tutela, poiché applicabile anche in caso di maternità a rischio e/o di malattia dei figli minori, diventi una "discriminazione nella discriminazione". Per i vertici dell'Int "la doverosa estensione alle professioniste e ai professionisti associativi delle tutele in caso di malattia, infortunio e maternità, che peraltro non incide assolutamente sulle competenze professionali, e neppure potrebbe essere considerata come una surrettizia equiparazione tra ordini e associazioni professionali, va considerata un atto di giustizia e di civiltà sociale." Nella missiva, inviata a Roccella, si legge, infine, nella nota dei tributaristi, è allegata una proposta di emendamento che risolverebbe la querelle sulle tutele in caso di malattia e ristabilirebbe l'equità di trattamento per donne e uomini che lavorano e danno lavoro.

author: Félix D.
title: Ce fruit que tout le monde adore contient beaucoup moins de pesticides que les autres, selon l’UFC Que-Choisir
text:
Ce fruit que tout le monde adore contient beaucoup moins de pesticides que les autres, selon l’UFC Que-Choisirmis à jour le 15 février 2024 à 22:33
Les fruits sont souvent contaminés par des pesticides. Un fruit l’est toutefois moins que les autres, selon l’UFC-Que choisir.
Consommer plus
de fruits et de légumes est l’un des conseils les plus connus en matière d’alimentation. Or, ces aliments sont malheureusement traités à l’aide de pesticides. Les pommes, les citrons, les poires et les tomates sont les victimes les plus fréquentes de ces traitements agricoles intenses.
Pour éviter de consommer des pesticides, dont les effets sur la santé ne sont bien évidemment pas bons, certains consommateurs se tournent alors vers des producteurs bios. Mais là encore, cette pratique n’est pas sans défauts. Il faut généralement accepter de payer ses courses de fruits et de légumes plus chers.
Comment vous procurez des fruits sans pesticides ?
Une méthode méconnue pour manger des fruits sans pesticides existe. Il suffit, en réalité, de se tourner vers certains aliments qui sont moins traités que les autres. Et heureusement, il existe des variétés qui sont moins touchées que les autres et qui s’avèrent plus saines.
Comme le rapporte le média PleineVie, c’est le litchi qui remporte la palme d’or du fruit le moins contaminé par les pesticides. Cette conclusion ressort d’une récente étude menée par l’UFC-Que-Choisir, qui la met à jour chaque année. Et cette nouvelle est excellente pour tous les fans de litchi.
Des fruits exotiques moins pollués que les autres par les pesticides
Bien que le résultat de cette étude puisse sembler paradoxal, les fruits exotiques ne sont visiblement pas les plus touchés par les pesticides. L’avantage du litchi est d’être apprécié par la plupart des personnes. Sa saveur est en effet rarement considérée comme repoussante.
Le fait qu’il soit aussi peu victime des traitements aux pesticides est ainsi une très bonne nouvelle pour ceux
qui souhaitent manger des fruits. Ce n’est d’ailleurs pas la première fois qu’un fruit exotique obtient un aussi bon score sur ce point. Le kiwi devançait le litchi quelques années plus tôt.
À lire également :
Pesticides : ces herbes aromatiques sont les plus contaminées, selon une étude Ce légume affiche un taux de pesticides inquiétant il faut absolument l’acheter bio Des légumes contaminés aux pesticides vendus en grande surface rappelés massivement
Une fréquence de contamination aux pesticides plus basse que pour les autres fruits
Le litchi, tout comme le kiwi, bénéficie ainsi d’une faible fréquence de contamination. Selon la même étude d’UFC-Que Choisir, ce taux s’établit à 15 % pour les litchis, contre 20 % pour le kiwi. En d’autres termes, vous bénéficiez de deux fruits exotiques réputés pour leur saveur et plus sains que les autres.
Cette étude ne prend pas en compte toute la pollution de ces fruits exotiques. Le litchi, comme le kiwi, nécessite d’être transporté depuis des pays lointains pour
arriver dans nos supermarchés. Si ce transport ne pollue pas le fruit, il signifie que son empreinte carbone n’est pas négligeable.

author: @indianexpress
title: Flight ops hit as dense fog covers Delhi, parts of North India
text:
Flight ops hit as dense fog covers Delhi, parts of North India
Delhiites woke up to thick fog and cold wave conditions on Friday morning, with low visibility expected to persist over the weekend.
[Express Web Desk](/agency/express-web-desk/)New Delhi | Updated: January 3, 2025 07:43 IST
Thick fog enveloped Delhi on Friday morning as the national capital continues to remain in the grip of a cold wave. An advisory was issued by the Delhi airport on January 3 in view of the dense fog, notifying a possibility of delays in flight operations throughout the day.
Visuals from Akshardham, Lodhi road and Shankar road showed thick fog and very low visibility on major routes in the city.
Further, the India Meteorological Department (IMD) predicted that cold wave will persist in the capital for the next couple of days, after which the temperature is likely to rise by a few degrees. IMD also said that ‘dense to very dense fog’ will continue in Delhi today and tomorrow.
As per an advisory issued by the Delhi International Airport Limited today at 6:35 am, all passengers flying in and out of the capital today need to contact their respective airlines to make sure there are no delays. While all flight operations are presently normal, it is likely that they can take a hit later in the day due to low visibility.
[#WATCH]| Delhi: Dense fog engulfs the national capital as cold wave grips the city.(Visuals from Shankar Road)
[pic.twitter.com/ztaJpxrwwT]— ANI (@ANI)
[January 3, 2025]
https://platform.twitter.com/widgets.js
The minimum temperature in Delhi on Friday settled at 8.5 degrees Celsius, while the maximum temperature is expected to be 20 degrees Celsius. Dense fog conditions in Delhi are expected to persist over the weekend.
IMD predicted that the national capital may receive light to moderate rainfall on Monday, January 6. Till then, the visibility in Delhi is expected to remain low.
The air quality index in Delhi remains in the ‘very poor’ category on Friday, recorded at 223 in the early hours of the day. Delhi’s AQI was recorded in the ‘very poor’ category for the fourth consecutive day today, with the air quality slipping marginally each day.
